facts.text: Lucknow Central Constituency is a double-member Constituency, one seat reserved for Scheduled Castes.
Polling took place on 31-1-1952, appellants declared elected having secured largest number of votes.
Respondent filed election petition on June 10, 1952 under S.81 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 alleging corrupt practices by appellants, praying election be declared void.
Appellants filed written statements denying allegations: first appellant on December 15, 1952; second on December 20, 1952.
Respondent No.4 (defeated candidate) filed written statement on December 3, 1952 alleging appellants obtained services of village officers like Lambardars and Sarpanches.
Respondent No.9 filed written statement on December 3, 1952 adopting No.4's allegations, adding Mukhias.
Respondent filed replication on January 10, 1953 alleging government servants worked for appellants, issued appeals, became polling agents.
Appellants objected to replication on January 24, 1953, applied for preliminary hearing on vagueness of allegations.
On October 31, 1953, Tribunal ordered para 7(c) not vague, directed petitioner to supply names of officials including Patwaris and Qanungoes, disregarded replication's new matters.
Respondent filed amendment application on February 27, 1953 under S.83(3) to add details to para 7(c): Village Headmen (Mukhias) with names, that they worked, issued appeals, became polling agents.
Tribunal allowed amendment on November 28, 1953 by majority, holding it particulars of charge in para 7(c), applying O.VI r.17 CPC.
Hearing of petition began in September 1954.

Election Tribunal on March 23, 1955 by majority set aside election: 1) appellants obtained assistance of four Mukhias contravening S.123(8); 2) first appellant employed Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande for payment exceeding Rule 118/Schedule VI, infringing S.123(7).

Para 7(c) of original petition: Respondents 1 and 2 could enlist support of government servants; details of eye relief camps and meetings at Kakori on Dec 16, 1951 and Dec 27, 1951 attended by officials, creating impression of support.
Ganga Prasad engaged by first appellant to prepare three carbon copies of Electoral Rolls, paid Rs.550 at Re.0-8-0 per 100 voters.
Viswanath Pande engaged to enter voters' names in printed cards, paid Rs.275 at Re.0-4-0 per 100 cards; both expenses shown in return against item K.
First appellant deposed Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande worked on contract basis.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal had power under S.83(3) to allow amendment to para 7(c) adding specific Mukhias as instances of obtaining assistance of government servants under S.123(8).
Whether O.VI r.17 CPC applies to election petitions before Tribunal via S.90(2), and if so, whether amendment permissible when new charge after limitation period.
Whether original para 7(c) sufficiently pleaded corrupt practice under S.123(8).
Whether first appellant employed Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande for payment in connection with election exceeding permitted number under Rule 118/Schedule VI, contravening S.123(7).

petitioner_arguments.text: Charge of employing four Mukhias not pleaded originally, came only via amendment Nov 28, 1953; Tribunal had no power under S.83(3) to allow as it adds new instances not particulars.
O.VI r.17 CPC does not apply: trial under S.90(2) means only hearing, not pre-hearing; amendment power excluded by S.83(3), S.92; subject to limitation under S.81.
Para 7(c) vague, does not allege actual obtaining assistance, only 'could enlist'; no list of particulars.
Even if amendment allowed, no evidence appellants obtained assistance of Mukhias.
Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande worked on contract basis for piece-work, not employed for payment; no evidence of employment contract.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.123(7), Rule 118, Schedule VI; distinction contract for services vs of service

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment under S.83(3) merely adds particulars to charge in para 7(c) of enlisting support of government servants including Mukhias who worked, appealed, became polling agents.
O.VI r.17 applies via S.90(2) to entire proceedings including amendment; even if late, permissible in interests of justice.
Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande employed for payment on piece-rate basis, exceeding permitted number.

court_reasoning.text: S.83(3) allows amendment/enlargement of particulars including new instances if relate to ground/charge in petition (S.123 corrupt practices via S.100(2)(b)).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grounds in S.81 are categories in S.100/101/123; facts in S.83(1); particulars in S.83(2),(3).

court_reasoning.text: S.90(2) applies CPC procedure to entire trial from transfer under S.86 to award, including pre-hearing like amendments.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial includes settling issues, directions; S.92 powers irreducible minimum, not excluding others.

court_reasoning.text: S.83(3) does not exclude O.VI r.17; latter applies to non-particulars amendments; no conflict.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.90(2) subject to Act only where conflict on same subject.

court_reasoning.text: But O.VI r.17 amendment cannot introduce new grounds/charges after limitation under S.81 if fresh petition barred.
Para 7(c) alleges only 'could enlist' support + impression via meetings; vague, no clear S.123(8) charge of actual obtaining assistance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Corrupt practice charges quasi-criminal, must be precise; amendment adds new charge, radically alters petition.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment order beyond power, set aside; finding on S.123(8) reversed.
No evidence of employment contract for Ganga Prasad/Viswanath Pande; mere piece-work contract insufficient; distinction contract for/of service.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on respondent; appellant's deposition of contract basis uncontradicted.

holdings.text: Tribunal has power under S.83(3) to allow new instances as particulars if charge/ground in petition.
O.VI r.17 applies to election petitions; trial under S.90(2) entire proceedings.
Amendment cannot introduce new charges after limitation period.
Para 7(c) insufficient to plead S.123(8); amendment invalid as new charge.
No corrupt practice under S.123(7); no employment proven.

precedents_cited.relevance: Particulars of corrupt practices need not be in petition body if charge stated; can be ordered later.
Similar to Beal v. Smith on particulars.
Amendment to add recently known facts for purity of election.
Latitude to amend unless withheld info.
Amendment power subject to limitation; no new charge post-bar.
Limitation relevant to discretion, but here jurisdictional.
Tribunal power to implead parties under CPC O.I rr.9,10,13.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheo Mahadeo Prasad v. Deva Sharan
precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous view S.83(3) excludes O.VI r.17.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for contract of employment: personal labour.
Election disputes to be determined with despatch.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing election petitions, corrupt practices, procedure, amendments, limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to trial of election petitions for amendments, parties.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Tribunal deemed civil court within meaning.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Tribunal's amendment order dated November 28, 1953 as beyond power, reversed findings of corrupt practices under S.123(8) and S.123(7), restoring appellants' election.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's judgment and order dated March 23, 1955 set aside.

key_quotes.text: "s. 83(3) is intended to clothe the Tribunal with a general power to allow not merely an amendment of particulars already given but also inclusion of fresh particulars, pleading new instances, subject to the condition that they are in respect of a ground set out in the petition."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of S.83(3) amendment power.

key_quotes.text: "The amendment cannot be allowed if it introduces a new charge after the time-limit for filing a fresh petition has expired."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits O.VI r.17 in election context.

key_quotes.text: "There is in law a well-established distinction between a contract for services, and a contract of service."
key_quotes.speaker: court
